coredata.dc:title: Preparation and application of polyacrylonitrile electrospun nanofiber-based all-solid-state composite electrolyte for lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Sarmad, Bushra
Gao, Lu
Kang, Weimin
coredata.dc:description:
The demand for lithium-ion batteries that are both safe and high-energy is growing. Liquid electrolytes are used in traditional lithium rechargeable batteries, which pose security hazards such as volatilization, flammability, and explosion. Most of the safety problems associated with liquid electrolytes could be addressed by solid-state electrolytes. This research firstly incorporated Li6 . 4La3Zr1 . 4Ta0 . 6O12 (LLZTO) ceramic nanoparticle filler into electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN) to obtain a composite nanofiber membrane, and then added it to polyethylene oxide (PEO) polymer as a nano-polymer filler to create an all-solid-state electrolyte. By incorporating the PAN/LLZTO composite nanofiber membrane, the resulting electrolyte gains a sturdy framework that enhances its overall mechanical strength (7.8 MPa) to prevent the growth of lithium dendrites during cycling. In addition, the addition of LLZTO particles can help promote chain segment motion in a PEO matrix by increasing the ratios of amorphous to crystalline phase, which is beneficial for the rapid migration of lithium ions in the electrolyte membrane. At the same time, the interaction between LLZTO and DMF solvent can also generate an alkaline atmosphere and then promotes the cyclization of PAN, thus enhancing the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte (6.5 × 10−5
c m
− 1
at 30 °C). The Li/Li symmetric battery assembled with the PEO-PAN/LLZTO composite electrolyte can stable cycling for 800 h at different current densities, and the Li/LiFePO4 battery can still maintain a high Coulomb efficiency of 99.7% after even 400 cycles under 1C. The research will lead to a promising electrolyte candidate for all-solid-state lithium metal batteries.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Li6 · 4La3Zr1 · 4Ta0 · 6O12 nanoparticle
3D network structure
All-solid-state composite electrolyte

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic illustration of PAN/LLZTO electrospun nanofibers membrane, and formation of the PEO-PAN/LLZTO solid composite electrolytes.

SEM images of (a) PAN, (b) PAN/LLZTO-5%, (c) PAN/LLZTO-8% and (d) PAN/LLZTO-10% nanofiber membranes. (e) XRD profiles of LLZTO powder, PAN and PAN/LLZTO nanofiber membranes. (f) FTIR of the PAN and PAN/LLZTO-8% nanofiber membranes.

(a) Cross-sectional and (b) Top-view SEM images of the PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte. EDS mapping images of (c) Zr and (d) O element in the PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte membrane. (e) DSC plots, (f) XRD profiles, (g) TG plots and (h) Stress–strain curves of composite electrolytes.
(a) Arrhenius plots and (b) LSV curves of the composite electrolytes.

The ability of Li/Li symmetric batteries to inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites under 50 °C. (a) Electrochemical impedance spectra of Li/Li symmetric cell with the PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte; Cycling performance of the Li/Li symmetric cells with the (b) PEO electrolyte, PEO-PAN electrolyte and (c) PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte under 100 μA cm−2. (d) Cycling performance of the Li/Li symmetric cell with the PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte under different current densities. (e) The SEM image of the lithium metal surface obtained from the Li/Li symmetric cell with the PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte after cycling 800 h under different current densities.

The cycle performance of the all-solid-state LiFePO4/Li battery with the PEO electrolyte, PEO-PAN electrolyte and PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte under 50 °C. (a) Electrochemical impedance plots, (b) Rate performances, (c) Cycling performance under 0.5C, (d) Cycling performance under 1C. (e) Charge/discharge voltage profiles of the LiFePO4/Li battery with the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte under 1C.

head.ce:title: Preparation and application of polyacrylonitrile electrospun nanofiber-based all-solid-state composite electrolyte for lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin, 300387, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes
School of Textile Science and Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin, 300387, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
The demand for lithium-ion batteries that are both safe and high-energy is growing. Liquid electrolytes are used in traditional lithium rechargeable batteries, which pose security hazards such as volatilization, flammability, and explosion. Most of the safety problems associated with liquid electrolytes could be addressed by solid-state electrolytes. This research firstly incorporated Li6 . 4La3Zr1 . 4Ta0 . 6O12 (LLZTO) ceramic nanoparticle filler into electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN) to obtain a composite nanofiber membrane, and then added it to polyethylene oxide (PEO) polymer as a nano-polymer filler to create an all-solid-state electrolyte. By incorporating the PAN/LLZTO composite nanofiber membrane, the resulting electrolyte gains a sturdy framework that enhances its overall mechanical strength (7.8 MPa) to prevent the growth of lithium dendrites during cycling. In addition, the addition of LLZTO particles can help promote chain segment motion in a PEO matrix by increasing the ratios of amorphous to crystalline phase, which is beneficial for the rapid migration of lithium ions in the electrolyte membrane. At the same time, the interaction between LLZTO and DMF solvent can also generate an alkaline atmosphere and then promotes the cyclization of PAN, thus enhancing the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte (6.5 × 10−5
c m
− 1
at 30 °C). The Li/Li symmetric battery assembled with the PEO-PAN/LLZTO composite electrolyte can stable cycling for 800 h at different current densities, and the Li/LiFePO4 battery can still maintain a high Coulomb efficiency of 99.7% after even 400 cycles under 1C. The research will lead to a promising electrolyte candidate for all-solid-state lithium metal batteries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: No data was used for the research described in the article.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium has historically been prized as the lightest and most active metal, capable of delivering the highest battery voltage [1]. Researchers have shown great interest in lithium metal batteries due to their remarkably high theoretical specific capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 and low reduction potential of 3.04 V compared to the standard hydrogen electrode [2,3]. Previously, most lithium metal battery research concentrated on liquid electrolyte systems. And traditional liquid electrolytes have the standard characteristics of high ionic conductivity and good electrode-wetting ability [4,5]. Unfortunately, rechargeable lithium metal batteries that utilize organic liquid electrolytes, which may consist of solvents like carbonates or ethers, tend to demonstrate unstable chemistry at the interface between the lithium and electrolyte. Furthermore, the organic substances present in the electrolyte have a high tendency to catch fire easily. This leads to a rapid decline in the effectiveness of the anode and also creates a serious safety hazard of potential fires and explosions that cannot be avoided [6–8].

Various alternative techniques have recently been explored and implemented to address the above Li-metal batteries limitations [7,9,10]. The invention and development of all-solid-state electrolytes (SSEs) is one of the most effective approaches [11–13]. The problem of electrolyte leakage can be fully avoided, and the creation of the SEI can be decreased because the all-solid-state lithium metal battery has no liquid component. In addition, SSEs can fundamentally change the behavior of Li deposition and block the Li dendrites [14–16]. Thus, propelled by expanding demand for storage devices with larger energy outputs and superior safety; Solid-state lithium metal batteries have proved their potential to overtake traditional liquid-based Li-ion batteries and fuel the future storage market [7,17–19].

Currently, solid electrolytes are mainly divided into solid polymer electrolytes, inorganic solid electrolytes, and composite electrolytes [12]. Specifically, significant lithium-ion mobility, high ionic conductivity, and higher mechanical properties can be achieved by inorganic solid electrolytes (mainly oxide-based or sulfide-based electrolytes). however, the high brittleness, high processing costs, and poor solid-solid interface contact of inorganic ceramic electrolytes limit their further development and still require systematic research [13,16,20–22]. In comparison, solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) have gained much research attention because of the following advantages: good processability and flexibility, dimensional stability, safety, and the ability to prevent lithium dendrite formation. Benefiting from the above advantages, SPEs can easily accommodate the volume expansion of the electrodes during battery cycling due to their mechanical flexibility and very close electrode adhesion, resulting in good electrolyte/electrode interface compatibility. However, the room-temperature ionic conductivity of SPEs is very low (<10−4 S/cm) and the ion mobility number is usually less than 0.3 [11,12,23,24].

Given the limits of a single-component electrolyte, composite solid-state electrolytes that combine the benefits of two or more different components appear to be a viable solution to the challenges mentioned above [25,26]. By integrating the complementary advantages of polymers and inorganics, as well as the collaborative effects of inorganic components and polymer and inorganic phases, composite electrolytes can achieve improved ionic conductivity and stability [27–29]. The filler in the composite electrolyte can be classified as a nanoparticle, nanowire, or three-dimensional (3D) fiber network filler based on its shape and structure. The three-dimensional (3D) fiber network has gotten a lot of attention because it can create a long-range organized ion transmission channel. Composite electrolytes made of polymers and garnets have the potential to increase the energy density of SSBs due to their numerous benefits, such as being portable, affordable, and simple to make [1,30,31]. Ever since the discovery of the ionic transport of PEO complexes with alkali metal salts by Wright and his colleagues [32] in 1975, PEO has been recognized as one of the most commonly used solid-polymer electrolytes [33]. As a result, numerous studies have been conducted to explore the feasibility of using composite electrolytes composed of PEO and garnet materials. In a study conducted by Zhang and colleagues [34] they examined how the ionic conductivity of PEO/LLZTO composite electrolytes is affected by the volume fraction of LLZTO particles. Their findings revealed that the ionic conductivity of the composite electrolytes amplified as the size of the garnet particles reduced from micro to nano-size. The best-performing electrolyte was observed to contain LLZTO particles smaller than 40 nm at a particle content of 12.7 vol%. At a temperature of 30 °C, this electrolyte achieved the greatest ionic conductivity of 2.1 ×
10
− 4
S
c m
− 1
. Regardless of these findings, the aggregation of nano-sized garnet powders in composite electrolytes impedes the ability to disperse LLZO nanoparticles into polymer matrices uniformly [33]. Several strategies have been implemented to address the limitations of PEO and enhance its ionic conductivity. Kun Fu [35] mixed ceramic garnet-type Li6 . 4La3Zr2Al0 . 2O12 (LLZO) in PVP to from 3D ceramic network when reinforced with PEO and Li salts. According to his research, the prepared composite structure is capable to provide structural reinforcement to enhance the mechanical properties of the polymer matrix, provides continuous Li+ transfer channels and exhibits an ionic conductivity of 2.5 ×
10
− 4
S cm−1 at room temperature; effectively blocking dendrites. Zhang et al. [36] developed a 3D ion-conducting network featuring high mechanically robust, flexible, and ion-conducting properties, as well as higher specific surface area by using LLZO nanoparticles that were synthesized and densely packed in polymer nanofibers by co-electrospinning with a hybrid polymer electrolyte (PVDF−PEO with LiTFSI) to form the 3D network. This 3D continuous network of electrospun nanofiber membranes formed by the overlapped fibers can be dispersed evenly in polymers, as a result, the maximum amount of nanofillers in the composite electrolyte is increased. This electrospun nanofiber network also provides continuous lithium ion transport channel and superior mechanical strength which in result gives the electrolyte high ionic conductivity and certain lithium dendrite growth inhibition ability [3]. In addition to the above, Li et al. [37] suggested a straightforward and affordable method for fabricating a hierarchically nanostructured 3D garnet framework using a cotton material that removes grease as a template, the PEO-lithium bis-trifluoromethyl sulfide (LiTFSI) polymer electrolyte is fully infused into a garnet structure, resulting in conductivity of 8.9 × 10−5 S cm−1 at a temperature of 25 °C. Essentially, a cotton material was used as a mold to create a structure for the electrolyte to fill, resulting in improved conductivity properties.

In this research article, we developed a composite electrolyte by using a combination of materials and techniques. Firstly, we dispersed Li6 . 40La3Zr1 . 40Ta0 . 60O12 (LLZTO) particles, which are an inorganic ceramic oxide-based garnet-type solid-state electrolyte (SSE), uniformly onto a Polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofiber membrane using electro-spinning. This created a composite PAN/LLZTO nanofiber. Next, we coated PEO polymer with LiTFSI onto the nanofiber membrane to prepare the final composite electrolyte. The 3D nanofiber network structure, which was created through electro-spinning, ensured that the long-range ordered lithium ions transmission channels were effectively maintained throughout the production and use of the composite electrolyte. The polymer polyacrylonitrile (PAN) contains a nitrogen group (─CN─) that attracts electrons (called an electron-withdrawing group) and gives the polymer a high potential for oxidation at the anode. Furthermore, the strong and stable 3D structure of the PAN electrospun nanofiber membrane prevents dendrite growth and short circuits in the battery. This helps to improve the battery's long-term stability and prevent potential problems that can occur over time. By combining an electrospun fiber membrane with PEO, it is possible to greatly expand the amorphous area of the PEO polymer. This creates more room for Li+ ions to move around, which makes it easier for them to travel through the electrolyte. As a result, the transport of Li+ ions is promoted, which helps to improve the overall efficiency of the battery.

The materials used in this study were purchased from various sources. The polymer, Polyacrylonitrile PAN, the solvent N, N-Dimethyl-formamide DMF, PEO (with a molecular weight of 600,000 g/mol), LiTFSI (with a purity of 99.99%), and acetonitrile (with a purity of 99.80%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. The oxide-based garnet-type Li6 . 40La3Zr1 . 40Ta0 . 60O12 (LLZTO) nanoparticles, which had a diameter of approximately 20–70 nm, were purchased from Changsha Research Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Co., Ltd. No additional processing of the materials was required before use in the study.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The fabrication of PAN/LLZTO composite nanofiber membrane
ce:section.ce:para: The electrospinning technique was utilized to create PAN/LLZTO nanofiber membranes. The process involved preparing a solution for electrospinning, wherein PAN nanoparticles were dissolved in 20 gm DMF and stirred for 2 h. Then, LLZTO with varying mass fractions were added to the mixture, followed by continuous stirring for another 2 h. The spinning solution was drawn and spun through a syringe under high voltage static electricity, with a speed of 0.5 mL/h and a voltage of 30 kV. The resulting nanofiber membrane was subjected to vacuum drying at 60 °C for 4 h to remove the residual solvent. The composite nanofiber membranes were named PAN/LLZTO-x, where x represented the mass fraction of LLZTO (0%, 5%, 8%, and 10%). For instance, PAN/LLZTO-5 referred to a membrane with 5% LLZTO content.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of PAN/LLZTO-PEO-LiTFSI composite polymer electrolyte
ce:section.ce:para: To create the PAN/LLZTO-PEO-LiTFSI electrolytes, a process called solution-casting was used. The first step was to combine PEO and LiTFSI with varying ratios of ethylene oxide [EO] to [LI] (8:1, 12:1, 16:1, and 20:1) in anhydrous acetonitrile in a specific order. This mixture was stirred vigorously for about 6 h until it became a uniform solution. Then, the solution was cast onto PAN/LLZTO membranes to make the PAN/LLZTO-PEO-LiTFSI electrolytes. After that, the composite electrolytes were dried in a vacuum oven under 60 °C for a whole day to eliminate any leftover solvent. Finally, the prepared electrolytes were moved to a glove box and kept for another 48 h before being used. The all-solid-state composite electrolyte membranes were cut into a circular shape with a diameter of 16 mm and a thickness of approximately 50–60 μm for electrochemical testing.

Scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, S-4800 Japan) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, H‐7650 Japan) was used to identify the morphology and microstructure of PAN/LLZTO nanofiber membranes and PEO-PAN/LLZTO electrolytes. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted by Bruker AXS D8 Discover machine with Cu Kα radiation 1.5418 A, in which the 2θ range ranged from 10° to 80°. In order to better understand the properties of the PAN/LLZTO nanofiber membranes and composite electrolytes, several analytical techniques were utilized. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were acquired on a TENSPR37 spectrometer to characterize the structure of materials. The formation of the LLZTO ceramic nanofiber was examined by conducting Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA-Q500) under a nitrogen atmosphere, with the temperature range set between 20 °C and 800 °C and a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

Additionally, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC Q5000IR TA) was conducted to obtain the melting point of the electrolyte. The temperature was increased from 20 °C to 120 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, and the gas atmosphere was nitrogen. Finally, the tensile shear property of the composite electrolyte was measured using a YG005E monofilament tensile tester with a stretching speed of 10 mm min−1. These analytical techniques helped to provide a comprehensive understanding of the properties and behavior of the PAN/LLZTO nanofiber membranes and composite electrolytes.

The stainless steel (SS)/composite electrolyte/SS sandwich structure batteries were used to characterize the ionic conductivities of the composite electrolytes at various temperatures ranging from 30 °C to 70 °C. The electrolyte with a diameter of 16 mm was subjected to electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) to measure its properties. The specific ionic conductivity (σ) values were obtained using formula (1), which is:
(1)
σ =
L
R S
where L is the thickness of the electrolyte (∼60 μm), R is the bulk resistance obtained from the real part of the impedance, and S is the area of the electrode SS (2 cm2). This formula helped to calculate the specific ionic conductivity, which is an important parameter for evaluating the performance of the electrolyte. By using EIS and formula (1), researchers were able to accurately measure and analyze the properties of the electrolyte, which provided important insights into its behavior and potential applications.

In addition, a Li symmetrical battery was constructed and tested using LAND CT2001A battery testing equipment. The test involved measuring the efficiency of lithium metal plating and stripping under different current density. This testing methodology helped to provide important insights into the performance of the battery and its potential applications.

By using the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) method with a progressively increasing voltage from 2.5 V to 6.0 V, The electrochemical stability window of composite electrolytes was investigated through the use of Li/composite electrolyte/SS batteries.

On a CHI660D electrochemical workstation test equipment, the results of all the aforementioned tests were recorded. Assembly of all-solid-state cells involved the combination of LiFePO4 cathode material, composite electrolyte, and lithium anode within a glove box filled with argon. In more detail, LiFePO4, carbon black, PEO, and LiTFSI were added to anhydrous acetonitrile at a mass ratio of 6:1:2:1, and the mixture was continually and aggressively stirred for a whole day to create a homogenous dispersion. The cathode material was created by this procedure. The dispersion was then brushed onto an aluminum foil that had been coated with carbon before being heated to 60 °C for 48 h in a vacuum drying box to thoroughly evaporate any remaining solvents. The diameter of the LiFePO4 cathode material was reduced to 14 mm, and the thickness was kept at 200 m. For the battery rate recovery performance test, the rate was adjusted to 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, and 2C correspondingly.

The schematic illustrations for the preparation of the PEO-PAN/LLZTO solid polymer composite electrolyte are presented in Fig. 1 . Firstly, the electrospinning solution of PAN polymer is obtained. PAN powders, TBAC inorganic branched salt, and LLZTO nanoparticles are added chronologically to the mixture of DMF and acetone solvent. This solution when running on high voltage in the electrospinning process fabricated a uniform PAN/LLZTO nanofiber membrane. This process is followed by solution casting of PEO and LiTFSI solution on the PAN/LLZTO nanofiber membrane. It is then dried to prepare this membrane into the PEO-PAN/LLZTO solid polymer composite electrolyte.

The SEM images of the electrospun PAN nanofiber and the PAN-LLZTO nanofibers at different concentrations are displayed in Fig. 2 . The electrospun pure PAN nanofibers have even surfaces and uniform fibrous structures in Fig. 2a. In Fig. 2b and c, it is clearly exhibited that as the amount of the LLZTO filler increased, the nanoparticles are fully embedded inside PAN nanofiber and randomly distributed free of aggregates, which is favorable for the Li-ion transport and the improvement of mechanical strength. However, when the concentrations of LLZTO increased to 10%, the aggregation occurred between LLZTO nanoparticles, which is not conducive to the transport of lithium ions along the PAN and LLZTO interfaces. Therefore, in order to achieve faster ion transport as much as possible, PAN/LLZTO-8% has been selected as the representative sample.

Fig. 2e displays the patterns of X-ray diffraction peaks observed in LLZTO powder samples, pure PAN membrane, and PAN/LLZTO membranes at various concentrations of LLZTO. It can be observed in the Braggs peaks of PAN/LLZTO membranes that these have the characteristic peaks of PAN and LLZTO powders at the same time, indicating that LLZTO has been successfully added into PAN nanofibers. The pure PAN nanofiber membrane has two characteristic diffraction peaks at 17° and 30°, and the broad humped peaks represent the amorphous nature of PAN. What is more noteworthy is that the peaks become a little sharper in intensity when the concentration of LLZTO increased to 10%, which means that the amorphous regions turn towards crystalline [42].

The introduction of LLZTO causes changes in the chemical structure of the PAN polymer. Fig. 2f displays the characterization of the interaction between DMF and LLZTO, as observed through FTIR analysis. The PAN was subjected to this interaction, and the resulting spectra were analyzed and depicted in the figure. According to the FTIR spectra in Fig. 2f. The peak at 2243 cm−1 is due to CN dangling bond. It can be clearly seen that the intensity of the CN peak in PAN/LLZTO-8% is much weaker than that in PAN, indicating the breaking of the CN bond. At the same time, the peak at 2900
c m
− 1
corresponding to CH or CH2 groups appears to show increased relative intensity for PAN/LLZTO-8% compared with the data obtained from pure PAN. In addition, it is worth noting that a new peak corresponding to the stretching vibration mode of the CN bond was observed in the PAN/LLLZTO-8% of 1581
c m
− 1
, indicating that the PAN skeleton undergoes cyclization after the introduction of LLZTO filler. Meanwhile, the intensity of the peak at 1415
c m
− 1
which corresponds to the stretching vibration of the CC bond also increases, implying that the PAN chains are segmented. To summarize, the FTIR findings, in conjunction with the prior research on DMF reactions, suggest that LLZTO has the potential to interact with DMF solvent. This interaction generates an alkaline atmosphere that promotes the cyclization of PAN. The cyclization procedure may have an effect on the intricate migration pattern of Li+ ions in the electrolyte membrane [41].

The top-view and side views of the PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte membrane were scanned by SEM, as shown in Fig. 3 a and b. This fabricated electrolyte membrane presents a smooth surface without any crack or interparticle space for dendrite penetration. The cross-sectional view which is about ∼50 μm shown in Fig. 3a specifies that the membrane contains a few layers of LLZTO nanofibers. The layered structuring of LLZTO nanofibers also stops the growth of Li dendrites, avoiding the cell from short-circuiting, and moreover gives the electrolyte membrane a high mechanical strength. This structure implies that PEO polymers and electrospun nanofiber membranes are mixed well, as a result, the composite electrolyte possesses the capability to inhibit the formation of lithium dendrites, thereby minimizing the risk of short circuits. This, in turn, enhances battery safety [34].

The above Fig. 3c and d shows the EDS mapping images of Zr and O elements in the PAN/LLZTO-8% nanofiber. It is presented so as to confirm the uniformity of the LLZTO dispersion in the electrolyte membrane more carefully. Fig. 3e illustrates the differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) profiles of the initial PAN-LiTFSI electrolyte and also the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-LiTFSI composite electrolyte including the LLZTO in ascending weight ratios. It expresses that as the amount of LLZTO in the electrolyte increases, the temperature at which the PEO polymer melts decreases. This effect is most significant at LLZTO concentrations of 8% and 10%. This change in melting temperature suggests that the PEO polymer segments have greater mobility and require less energy for movement at these concentrations of LLZTO. These findings clearly show that the LLZTO helps to facilitate the movement of PEO polymer molecular chains, which in turn increases the number of locations for lithium ions to migrate to in the composite electrolyte.

The purity of LLZTO powders was initially checked using XRD. As shown in Fig. 3f, the analysis confirms that there are no impurities in the LLZTO powder, meaning that they are not likely to be the source of the heterogeneity in the ceramic particles. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of LLZTO powders, PEO, PEO-PAN, and composite electrolytes are displayed. Fig. 2e illustrates that the PEO electrolyte displays two noticeable diffraction peaks at 19° and 23°, whereas the pure PAN nanofiber membrane presents a distinctive diffraction peak at 17°. PEO has a significant level of crystallinity, which makes it difficult for molecule segments to move freely within the PEO crystalline region, which results in poor Li ion migration and low ionic conductivity [44,45]. Post-solution casting, the produced composite electrolyte shows the typical peaks of PEO and PAN simultaneously, demonstrating complete polymer blending. The characteristic diffraction peak of LLZTO also starts to show up in the PEO-PAN/LLZTO composite electrolytes once LLZTO is added to the PAN nanofiber membrane, confirming that the polymer matrix and ceramic filler were well-matched. In addition to this, the peak intensity increases as the LLZTO content rises. Furthermore, all three PEO-PAN/LLZTO composite electrolytes had evident lower PEO crystallinity than the LLZTO-free composite electrolyte. It reveals that the PEO crystallization behavior was effectively prevented by the addition of a 3D fiber network made of PAN and LLZTO. It's very fascinating to learn that the crystallinity of PEO polymers in the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte is obviously lower than that of the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-10% composite electrolyte. At the PAN/LLZTO interaction, there are close chemical interactions that assisted PAN's partial dehydrogenation and resulted in a locally conjugated structure [45]. The amorphous region area in the polymer matrix is increased by the PAN/LLZTO membrane, which is important for the rapid movement of lithium ions, as shown by the results presented above.

The thermal stability was examined using TGA. Fig. 3g shows the TG thermogram of the pure and composite electrolytes with different amounts of LLZTO. The TG curve displays two sites of weight loss for the electrolyte created from a composite of pure PAN nanofiber membrane and PEO-LiTFSI. The evaporation of residual solvent results in the first weight loss seen at around 100 °C [45]. Next, the weight loss can be seen falling cuttingly from around 320 °C to about 420 °C, signifying that the electrolyte started to experience a complete thermal breakdown. In particular, the electrolyte with different amount LLZTO shows similar thermal degradation temperature, demonstrating that the addition of LLZTO can help the composite electrolyte maintain high thermal stability, thus increasing the battery's safety [46].

Good mechanical properties are critical for electrolyte use in Li batteries. The tensile strength of electrolytes is reported in order to assess the impact of LLZTO on the mechanical strengths of composite electrolytes. Fig. 3h shows the stress-strain curves of the PEO, PEO-PAN and PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte membrane. At room temperature, the tensile strength of pure PEO is 1.5 MPa. The tensile strength of the PEO-PAN electrolyte then rises to 5.2 MPa following the addition of the PAN nanofiber membrane, showing that the electrospun nanofiber membrane can serve as a sturdy foundation for the composite electrolyte. Then, the tensile strength of PAN was significantly enhanced by the 3D fiber network of PEO-PAN/LLZTO reinforcement with 8% LLZTO particles to 7.2 MPa. It enhances the mechanical properties of CSE, which is useful for preventing the development of lithium dendrites and lowering the danger of internal short circuits in batteries. Thus, improving the electrochemical performance and safety of the battery [47].

Ionic conductivity is an important performance indicator for solid electrolytes. The Arrhenius plot in Fig. 4 a illustrates the ionic conductivity's temperature independence [41]. At first, the PEO-PAN electrolyte has better ionic conductivity than pure PEO electrolyte, proving that the PAN nanofiber membrane is helpful for ion transmission. The ionic conductivity of PEO-PAN/LLZTO-LiTFSI-8% electrolyte can reach 6.5 × 10−5
c m
− 1
. The aftermentioned findings make it clear that the high ionic conductivity of the composite electrolyte is not simply due to ion transport through the salt-filled polymer phase or the bare ceramic phase. The cyclization PAN nanocoating enhances the ionic conductivity of garnet by creating channels for interparticle Li+ conduction in the ceramic phase [41]. Moreover, LLZTO exhibits good compatibility with PEO polymer matrices. The Li ions in LLZTO can occupy both La3+ and Zr4+ sites in the crystal structure, creating a mixed oxide with high stability and favorable Li+ mobility. This structure allows Li ions to move more freely through the electrolyte, leading to higher ionic conductivity [48]

The electrochemical stability window (LSV) of these CSEs was investigated. The LSV curves of the PEO, PEO-PAN, and PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte membranes are shown in Fig. 4b. The pure PEO's current value climbs dramatically about 3.8 V (vs. Li+/Li), as shown in the figure, indicating that the PEO starts to break down at that voltage. Comparatively, the electrolyte with the composition PEO-PAN/LLZTO-LiTFSI-8% did not notice a significant change in current value, demonstrating how effectively the addition of LLZTO/PAN composite nanofiber membrane can increase the electrochemical stability of the electrolyte. The broader electrochemical stability windows found here demonstrated that CSEs were appropriate for high-pressure all-solid-state lithium batteries. The following phenomenon was responsible for this improvement: (a) the strong oxidation resistance of PAN fiber (b) The innovative fiber network structure enhanced the stability of the electrolyte. (c) LLZTO demonstrated high stability to Li metal [45,49].

Electrochemical impedance spectra of Li/Li symmetric cell with the PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte was 408.2 Ω as shown in Fig. 5 a. By putting together Li symmetric batteries, the electrochemical stability between the electrolyte and Li metal anode as well as the electrolyte's ability to inhibit Li dendrite development were investigated. To emulate the charging and discharging operation of a lithium metal battery, galvanostatic cycling tests are carried out on Li/Li symmetric batteries with pure PEO, PEO-PAN and PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolytes. Fig. 5b and c shows the voltage-time curves of the Li/Li symmetric cells. It is evident from these graphs that the voltage of the Li/PEO/Li symmetric cell reduces suddenly from 0.4 V and short-circuited in the symmetrical battery around 500 h. Also, the Li/PEO-PAN/Li symmetric cell started fluctuating from 0.3 V at 420 h and this ultimately results in the short-circuit occurrence at around 850 h. This situation occurred because the polarisation voltage increased, the junction between the electrolyte and Li metal was broken, and also, due to low IC and weak mechanical properties of the PEO electrolyte, short circuits ensued [3]. Quite the reverse, the addition of 3D PAN/LLZTO nanofiber network electrolyte, showed a stable cycle performance. The voltage of the Li/Li symmetric battery with the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte exhibits reasonably remarkable cycle stability, remaining constant throughout the 1800 h cycle with no discernible variation. The reasons for this enhancement might be: (a) The 3D PAN/LLZTO composite network brought about sturdy framework support and improved the electrolyte's mechanical characteristics. (b) The homogenous dispersion of LLZTO ceramic particles led to the uniform distribution of Li+ to facilitate the uniform Li deposition. The anions were fixed and a uniformly distributed space charge layer was created [30]. (c) PAN and LLZTO may have had close chemical interactions at their interface that aided in the partial cyclization of PAN and led to the formation of a local conjugated structure. These conjugated structures created a continuous Li+ conduction route, facilitated quick Li+ exchange at the PAN/LLZTO contact, and stimulated uniform Li+ deposition [41]. Fig. 5d shows the cycling performance of the Li/Li symmetric cell with the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte under different current densities. At linear densities of 100, 150, and 200 μA
c m
− 2
the voltages were 0.4 V, 0.7 V, and 1.2 V respectively. Additionally, after 800 h of cycling, the symmetrical battery displayed a flat voltage profile, and no short circuits happened. Fig. 5e displays the surface morphology of lithium metal obtained from the Li/Li symmetric cell with the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte after 800 h of cycling under varying current densities, as observed through SEM imaging. The lithium metal exhibits a mostly even and flat surface morphology, indicating that the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte was successful in preventing the growth of lithium dendrites and promoting uniform lithium deposition [50].

Fig. 6 a displays the electrochemical impedance plots of LiFePO4/Li battery with the PEO electrolyte, PEO-PAN electrolyte and PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte. The impedance of the LiFePO4/PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8%/Li battery is 252.8 Ω, which is lower than that of LiFePO4/PEO/Li battery (565.4 Ω) and the LiFePO4/PEO-PAN/Li battery (308.7 Ω) (Fig. 5a.). This suggests that the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte has formed a strong and efficient wetting interface with the lithium metal anode and LiFePO4 cathode.

Fig. 6b shows the rate capability of LiFePO4/Li batteries with three different electrolytes at various rates. The discharge capacities of the LiFePO4/PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8%/Li battery are much greater than those of the LiFePO4/PEO/Li battery and the LiFePO4/PEO-PAN/Li battery at current densities of 0.1, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0C; which are 152.4145.9140.5, and 132.4 mAh g−1, correspondingly. Additionally, the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte used in the LiFePO4/Li battery assembly provides a more stable and greater Coulomb efficiency (99.6%) than the pure PEO electrolyte and the PEO-PAN electrolyte. The PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte composited with the PAN/LLZTO composite electrospun nanofiber membrane has an electrochemical stability window of up to 5.0 V, which helps to avoid and reduce the degradation of the electrolyte and the occurrence of side reactions between the electrolyte and the electrode in the charge-discharge voltage setting range of 2.5 V–4.2 V. This ultimately leads to high Coulomb efficiency in the battery.

Fig. 6c shows the results of an investigation into the long-term cycling capabilities of LiFePO4/Li batteries built with pure PEO electrolyte, PEO-PAN electrolyte and PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte at 0.5C. It demonstrates that the LiFePO4/PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8%/Li battery's initial discharge capacity is 160.9 mA h
g
− 1
and that, with a capacity retention rate of 94.1%, it can still be discharged to 151.4 mA h
g
− 1
after 300 cycles. Furthermore, the battery's ability to efficiently convert stored energy to electrical energy, known as Coulomb efficiency, can reach up to 99.8% after repeated cycles, indicating that the battery has excellent long-term stability. However, after approximately 300 cycles, the discharge capacity of the LiFePO4/PEO/Li and LiFePO4/PEO-PAN/Li battery decreases to 93.4 mA h g−1 and 118.3 mA h g−1, respectively. This is mainly due to the decreased ionic conductivity and inability to effectively prevent the formation of lithium dendrites. Consequently, it can be concluded that the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% electrolyte is beneficial for the development of high-performance lithium metal batteries.

Fig. 6d shows the results of the cycle life stability at 1C of LiFePO4/Li batteries built with PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte. The battery exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 140.1 mA h g−1, and it maintains a high Coulomb efficiency of 99.7% after undergoing 400 cycles. These electrochemical tests prove that the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte shows great long-term cycling stability. After a specific number of cycles under 1C, the LiFePO4/PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8%/Li cell's respective charge and discharge curves are measured and shown in Fig. 6e. It is apparent that the battery's charging and discharging curves at various cycles have a comparatively flat platform. The battery's respective discharge capacity after its first, 100th, 200th, and 400th cycles are 140.1136.2133.4, and 126.8 mA h g−1. The utilization of the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte is beneficial in improving the overall electrochemical performance of the battery.

The purpose of this study is to develop a solid composite electrolyte that can be utilized in solid-state lithium metal batteries, enabling them to have high energy density and performance. To achieve this, the researchers combined electrospinning and solution casting methods to create a composite of LLZTO, PAN, and PEO polymers. This combination led to strong chemical and physical interactions between the components, ensuring the swift transport of Li ions while also providing mechanical strength to the composite electrolyte. Furthermore, the composite electrolyte has been shown to be effective in inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites. The LLZTO particles promote chain segment motion in a PEO matrix by increasing the ratios of amorphous to crystalline phase. At the same time, the interaction between LLZTO and DMF solvent generates an alkaline atmosphere and then promotes the cyclization of PAN, which has a positive impact on the complex migration patterns of Li ions in electrolyte membranes. The problems of low ionic conductivity were solved, and the poor interfacial compatibility were resolved. In addition, the introduction of the three-dimensional PAN/LLZTO composite nanofibers significantly improves the overall mechanical properties of the composite electrolyte, the mechanical strength can be reached up to 7.2 MPa. The Li/PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8%/Li symmetric battery's voltage stayed constant during 1800 h at 100 μA
c m
− 2
. Additionally, after undergoing 400 cycles under 1C, the all-solid-state Li/LiFePO4 battery composited with the PEO-PAN/LLZTO-8% composite electrolyte exhibited a discharge-specific capacity of 140.1 mA h g−1 and maintained a high Coulomb efficiency of 99.7%. The fabrication and implementation of the composite electrolyte is expected to give a viable technique for producing high-performance lithium batteries.

We wish to draw the attention of the editor to the following facts which may be considered as potential conflicts of interest and to significant financial contributions to this work. We warrant that the article is the authors' original work, hasn't received prior publication and isn't under consideration for publication elsewhere. We also confirm that the manuscript has been read and approved by all named authors and that there are no other persons who satisfied the criteria for authorship but are not listed. We further confirm that the order of authors listed in the manuscript has been approved by all of us. We understand that the corresponding author is the sole contact for the editorial process. Weimin Kang is responsible for communicating with the other authors about progress and submission of revisions. All the authors listed have approved the revised manuscript. Finally, the authors declare no competing financial interests.
